Award.AwardTitle: A US:Indonesia workshop to explore the dimensions of biodiversity
Award.AbstractNarration:
This workshop will bring together researchers from the US and Indonesia to discuss the critical issues in biodiversity that affect the Pacific Rim in general and Indonesia in particular. Leading biodiversity investigators from the US will integrate with their Indonesian counterparts who are working to understand the role of Indonesia's extensive and diverse fauna, flora and microbiota. The waters surrounding the ca. 17,000 Indonesian Islands are home to over a quarter of the Earth's identified fish species, and more than 60% of the hard coral species. Most taxa are endemic - these Islands afford many unique niches for organisms to evolve and interact.

Nature is under constant threat as human activity encroaches on the amazingly diverse and unexplored habitats in Indonesia. The coral reefs, in particular, are at considerable risk. It is essential that biodiversity scientists explore these habitats and provide critical data needed to drive conservation efforts and priorities. The workshop will promote international collaboration to enable future partnerships and student exchange.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Dimensions of Biodiversity program is a 10-year effort to transform our understanding of biodiversity. Indonesia is one of the most important biodiversity hotspots in the world. Even though it occupies less than 2 percent of the terrestrial surface, Indonesia contains over 10 percent of the mammals and more than 15 percent of the cataloged birds, reptiles, and amphibians on the planet. The waters surrounding the approximately 17,000 Indonesia Islands are home to over a quarter of the fish species that have been identified as well as more than 60% of the hard coral species identified. Most of those species are endemic, and many are believed to have evolved in situ, isolated in the unique niches that the islands afford. To understand the planet's biodiversity requires a detailed understanding of both the terrestrial and aquatic flora and fauna that surround Indonesia.

 The US:Indonesia workshop to explore the dimensions of biodiversity program held three workshops aimed at improving our understanding of this critical region of the planet.

 The first was held at the Indonesian Institute of Sciences (LIPI) Research Center in Cibinong, Republic of Indonesia from 4-6 February 2013. This workshop had twenty-four participants from Indonesia and fourteen participants from the United States of America. The workshop brought together researchers from the US and Indonesia to discuss the critical issues in biodiversity that affect the Pacific Rim in general and Indonesia in particular. Lead investigators of the National Science Foundation's Dimensions of Biodiversity integrated with local researchers who are working to understand the role of the diverse flora and fauna in the Indonesian ecosystem. The workshop bought together US and Indonesian ecologists and evolutionary biologists to exchange ideas and explore collaborative possibilities for scientific projects that would fit the Dimensions of Biodiversity program. The scientific program was chaired by Dr. Wie Witjaksono, Director, Institute of Biotechnology, LIPI-Biotek, Cibinong, Bogor, Indonesia and Dr. Robert Edwards, San Diego State University, San Diego, CA, USA. 

The second and third workshops were smaller in scale than the original, and were designed to promote one-to-one interactions between graduate students from the United States and Indonesia. These workshops focused on the application of next-generation sequencing and bioinformatics to study biodiversity in marine ecosystems. The second workshop was held at Diponegoro University (UNDIP), a private university on the outskirts of Semarang, Java, and the third workshop was held at Hasanuddin University (UNHAS) in Makassar, Sulawesi. The workshops were designed to be student-centric to promote interactions between students. After brief introductions of the faculty present and short summaries of their research, the US students lead the workshops and presented their research. There workshops also included open ended question and answer periods for students to discuss the material.

 The first workshop enabled an open discussion of the state of biodiversity research in Indonesia, promoted the development of a separate Indonesian National Science Foundation, and development of new collaborative research. The subsequent workshops lead to closer integration between San Diego State University in the United States and UNIDIP and UNIHAS in Indonesia, and resulted in the submission of joint grants to the Partnerships for Enhanced Engagement in Research (PEER) science program.
